Shrapnel from the exploding pen penetrated his artery in his neck, cutting off blood to his brain. Brown was vaping for the first time with his newly-purchased e-cigarette when the explosion happened.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: B'desh seals Myanmar border amid influx of Hindu, Buddhist refugees
data.content: Bangladesh has sealed off the border with Myanmar amid the fresh influx of refugees fleeing reported violence in the Rakhine State. Ethnic and religious groups, including Buddhists and Hindus, have been trying to cross into Bangladesh, Foreign Minister AK Abdul Momen said. Over 7 lakh Rohingya Muslims fled to Bangladesh following the military crackdown in Myanmar in August 2017.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: UK man travels 320 kms to see injured mom, reaches before ambulance
data.content: A 48-year-old UK man named Mark Clements who travelled nearly 320 kilometres on a bus, two tubes and two trains from London to Exmouth, to see his 77-year-old injured mother, reached her before the ambulance. His mother had suffered a broken hip after a fall. The paramedics didn't arrive until seven hours after the initial ambulance call was made.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Stay out of politics: Pakistan Supreme Court tells military
data.content: Pakistan's Supreme Court has told the military to not meddle in politics, criticising its media wing for commenting on political matters. The top court also ordered Pakistan's intelligence agencies including the ISI, to operate within their mandate. The court's order came while delivering a verdict on the Tehreek-e-Labaik Pakistan's 2017 Faizabad sit-in, after it accused a minister of blasphemy.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: New Mexico's Governor runs through walls in video trolling Trump
data.content: Trolling US President Donald Trump over his proposed US-Mexico border wall, Governor of the US state of New Mexico, Michelle Lujan Grisham, has posted a video wherein she runs through four walls. "We gotta bust through some walls to make changes," she says before running through the first wall and ends with breaking a wall with Trump's photo on it.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: Hawaii considering bill to raise legal smoking age to 100 years
data.content: Hawaii is considering a bill that could raise the legal smoking age to 100 years, effectively banning cigarettes for the majority of people. It suggests the smoking age should go up to 30 in 2020, 40 in 2021, 50 in 2022, and 60 in 2023, until finally in 2024, people would need to be 100 years old to buy cigarettes.
data.author: Pragya Swastik

data.title: Chinese student jailed for taking pictures of US naval base
data.content: A Chinese student has been sentenced to a year in prison after he pleaded guilty to illegally taking pictures at the Naval Air Station Key West in US. Zhao Qianli went directly to an area that contains a range of satellite dishes and antennas called the Farm and took videos and multiple photographs of the equipment there, court documents said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Islamic State will be defeated 100% by next week: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump said the Islamic State may lose 100% of its territory in Iraq and Syria by next week. "Rest assured, we'll do what it takes to defeat every ounce and every last person within the ISIS madness and defend our people from radical Islamic terrorism," he added. Trump has ordered the withdrawal of US troops from Syria.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ex-Brazil Prez Lula gets 13-year jail in new corruption case
data.content: Former Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has been given nearly 13 years in prison in a new corruption conviction. He was found guilty of accepting bribes in the form of a renovation of a farmhouse. He was sentenced to over 12 years in prison last year for accepting an apartment in return for contracts awarded to a firm.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Woman arrested for starting fire in Paris building that killed 10
data.content: French authorities have arrested a 40-year-old woman over suspicions of starting a fire in an eight-storey building in Paris, killing at least 10 people and injuring over 30 others. The woman, who is known to have had mental health issues, allegedly started the fire following an argument with her neighbour who is a professional fireman.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Why did US women lawmakers wear white to State of the Union?
data.content: Democratic women lawmakers wore white to US President Donald Trump's State of the Union (SOTU) address on Tuesday to celebrate 100 years of women having the right to vote. It was also a tribute to honour the people who came out to vote in the recent midterm elections that gave the Democrats the majority in the House of Representatives.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Macedonia signs accession deal to become 30th NATO member
data.content: Macedonian Foreign Minister Nikola Dimitrov and NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg on Wednesday signed an accession agreement, clearing the way for the Balkan nation to become the military alliance's 30th member. Each NATO member state now needs to ratify the accession deal. The country is expected to join NATO under the name of the Republic of North Macedonia.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indian-American entrepreneur Gurinder Khalsa enters politics
data.content: Gurinder Singh Khalsa, an Indian-American philanthropist and entrepreneur, has decided to run for the City Council of Fishers in the US' Indiana state. He attributed the decision to enter politics to an "interest in public policy...along with the desire to give back to (his) community". Khalsa had led a campaign for the US to change its headgear policy at airports.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Russia to develop new missile systems after nuclear treaty exit
data.content: Russia has said it is planning to develop new missile systems by 2021 after both Russia and the US suspended their involvement in the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty which banned both countries from stationing short and intermediate-range, land-based missiles in Europe. After suspending the treaty last week, Russia has said it'll exit the deal in six months, following the US.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Nobel winner Arias accused of assault by 4 women in 48 hrs
data.content: Nobel Peace Prize winner and former Costa Rican President Oscar Arias has been accused of assault by four women in 48 hours. A nuclear disarmament activist was the first to accuse Arias, claiming he assaulted her at his home in 2014. Arias received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1987 for his efforts to end the civil wars in Central America.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Vatican clarifies Pope's remark on sexual slavery of nuns
data.content: The Vatican has clarified a comment by Pope Francis on the "sexual slavery" of nuns within a French congregation, saying he was referring to "manipulation or a type of abuse of power that is reflected in sexual abuse". Pope Francis had made the comment while admitting for the first time to the problem of priests and bishops sexually abusing nuns.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Venezuela seizes shipment of US-made weapons amid ongoing tension
data.content: Venezuelan authorities on Wednesday seized a shipment of US-made weapons which was likely sent from Miami. The weapons were seized at the Arturo Michelena International Airport in Valencia. This comes after the US said it doesn't rule out military action in Venezuela to address the political crisis that occurred after opposition leader Juan Guaidó declared himself the country's interim President.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US supports dictators, butchers & extremists in Middle East: Iran
data.content: The US' "hostility has led it to support dictators, butchers and extremists" in the Middle East, who have only brought "ruin" to the region, Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif said on Wednesday. Zarif's statement came in response to US President Donald Trump's State of the Union speech where he called Iran "the world's leading state sponsor of terror".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Special place in hell for Brexit supporters without plan: Tusk
data.content: European Council President Donald Tusk said British leaders who promoted Brexit without a plan on how to deliver it deserve a "special place in hell". His comments came following talks with Irish PM Leo Varadkar over the Irish backstop issue. "It's a question for Tusk as to whether he considers...that kind of language helpful," British PM Theresa May's office said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Woman throws cigarette butt on road, man throws it back into her car
data.content: A video of a man named Magnus confronting a woman who threw a cigarette butt out of her car's window at a signal in Australia has gone viral. "This poor lady's cigarette accidentally fell out of her hand...I kindly returned it to her...Chivalry still exists," Magnus joked.

data.title: Trump to meet Kim Jong-un for 2nd summit in Vietnam on Feb 27-28
data.content: US President Donald Trump has confirmed that he'll hold his second summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un in Vietnam on February 27 and 28. "If I had not been elected president of the United States, we would right now, in my opinion, be in a major war with North Korea," Trump said during the State of the Union Address.
data.author: Arshiya Chopra

data.title: MMA fighter who escaped police van found hiding in dustbin
data.content: A mixed martial arts fighter suspected of two murders, who had escaped from Texas police, was found hiding in a rubbish bin. Cedric Marks had escaped from a prison transport vehicle after it stopped at a McDonald's in Conroe, near Houston. He was being transferred to Temple, Texas to face charges on Sunday when he fled.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Father of US man killed in Andaman blames 'extreme Christianity'
data.content: The father of John Chau, a missionary allegedly killed by Andaman's Sentinelese tribe last year, has blamed "extreme Christianity" for the death of his son. "John is gone because the Western ideology overpowered my [Confucian] influence," he said. Chau illegally travelled to the North Sentinel Island to convert the tribe to Christianity.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indian Coast Guard evacuates ill baby in Maldives' Gan Island
data.content: Indian Coast Guard pilots successfully evacuated a critically ill infant in the Maldives' Gan Island on Monday. "The noble efforts of the Indian technical team, in collaboration with the Maldives National Defence Force Air Wing, are truly valued," Chief of Defence Force of the Maldives, Major General Abdulla Shamaal said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Indian man in US smuggled 400 people, took up to ₹60 lakh from each
data.content: A 60-year-old Indian man has pleaded guilty for his role in a conspiracy to smuggle individuals from India to the US for profit. Yadvinder Singh Bhamba personally assisted around 400 individuals to unlawfully enter the US between 2013 and 2015. Individuals paid between $30,000 (over ₹20 lakh) and $85,000 (over ₹60 lakh) to be smuggled from India to the US.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Man attacked by mountain lion, fights back & suffocates it to death
data.content: A man who was attacked by a mountain lion while running on a northern Colorado trail in US fought back and killed the animal by suffocating it, wildlife officials said. The lion, less than a year old, bit him on his face and wrist. The man was hospitalised with serious injuries and is expected to make a full recovery.
data.author: Daisy Mowke

data.title: Pope Francis becomes first Pope to visit Arabian Peninsula
data.content: Pope Francis reached the UAE on Sunday for the first-ever visit by a head of the Catholic Church to the Arabian Peninsula. Pope Francis and Sheikh Ahmed al-Tayeb, the Grand Imam of Egypt's Al-Azhar mosque, signed a 'Document on Human Fraternity for World Peace and Living Together'. The UAE said Pope's visit reflects its history as a "cradle of diversity".
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: I'm going to shoot up a school: US boy tells Siri; gets list of schools
data.content: A middle school student in Indiana, US got a list of schools after he told Apple's digital assistant Siri, "I am going to shoot up a school." The 13-year-old, who took a screenshot of Siri's response and posted it on social media, was arrested and charged with intimidation. His friends on social media had alerted the police.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: UN monitors say North Korea protecting nuclear missiles
data.content: UN monitors have said North Korea is protecting its nuclear and ballistic missiles, adding that sanctions against the nation were proving ineffective. This comes ahead of the second summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. North Korea has said it'll never unilaterally give up its nukes unless the US first removes any threat to it.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Don't overburden Iraq with your own issues: Iraq President to Trump
data.content: After US President Donald Trump said he would ask US troops stationed in Iraq to "watch" Iran, Iraqi President Barham Salih said, "Don't overburden Iraq with your own issues." Salih added US troops in Iraq are there as part of an agreement between the two countries with a specific mission of combating terrorism and that they should stick to that.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Pope admits nuns kept as sex slaves by priests
data.content: Pope Francis for the first time admitted to sexual abuse of nuns by Catholic priests and bishops, including sexual slavery. He added that his  predecessor, Pope Benedict XVI, shut down an entire congregation of nuns who were being abused by priests. His remarks came after a magazine claimed that in some cases nuns were forced to abort priests' children.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: US man pays record ₹78 lakh to hunt Pakistan's national animal
data.content: A US national has paid record $110,000 (over ₹78 lakh) as permit fee to hunt Pakistan's national animal markhor. Although hunting the markhor is illegal in Pakistan, it is legal under the government's trophy hunting programmes. As per reports, Pakistani authorities distribute 80% of the money among the local community, whereas the remaining 20% goes to the government exchequer.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Those not giving birth responsible for falling population: Japan Dy PM
data.content: Japan's Deputy Prime Minister Taro Aso has said that those who "didn't give birth" are to be blamed for the country's declining population. "There are lots of strange people who say the elderly are to blame, but that is wrong," he added. In 2017, around 9.5 lakh babies were born while the number of deaths rose to around 13 lakh.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: 11-year-old, bullied for last name 'Trump', invited to Prez's speech
data.content: Joshua Trump, an 11-year-old who has been bullied in school for his last name, will be one of US President Donald Trump and First Lady Melania Trump's guests at the State of the Union Address, the White House announced. "He said he hates himself, and he hates his last name...as a parent that's scary," Joshua's mother Megan Trump Berto said.
data.author: Ankush Verma

data.title: Rapper 21 Savage faces deportation from US
data.content: Rapper 21 Savage faces deportation from the US after authorities claimed he is British and staying in the US illegally. The rapper, whose real name is Sha Yaa Bin Abraham-Joseph, was arrested over accusations that he had overstayed his visa by more than a decade. He was convicted on felony drug charges in the US state of Georgia in 2014.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Instagram to add 'sensitivity screens' after UK teen suicide
data.content: Instagram head Adam Mosseri said the platform will hide self-harm imagery of 'cutting' behind 'sensitivity screens' following 14-year-old British girl Molly Russell's suicide. Molly's parents believe she took her life after viewing graphic images of self-harm on Instagram and Pinterest. We let people "share that they are struggling", but remove posts that promote such activity, Mosseri added.
data.author: Arundhati Rawat

data.title: India gets consular access to 117 of 129 students detained in US
data.content: India has obtained consular access to 117 of the 129 Indian students detained in the US in a 'pay-to-stay' visa scam, the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) said. The students are being assisted in obtaining legal advice, the MEA added. The students are accused of enrolling at a fake university to maintain their student visa status to obtain work permits.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Saudi gave US-made weapons to al-Qaeda-linked groups: Report
data.content: Saudi Arabia and the UAE transferred US-made weapons to al-Qaeda-linked groups, hardline Salafi militias, and other factions fighting the war in Yemen, according to a CNN report. The Saudi-led coalition used US-manufactured weapons "as a form of currency to buy the loyalties of militias", the report added. Iran-backed Houthi rebels got hold of US-made Mine Resistant Ambush Protected vehicles.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 4 women killed every day in Brazil this year: Report
data.content: Four women have been killed every day so far this year in Brazil, the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights (IACHR) said. IACHR called the rate "alarming" and called upon the Brazilian government to take more steps to prevent and prosecute femicides. Femicide is the killing of a woman by a man because of her gender.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: China, Taiwan clash with propaganda videos on Lunar New Year
data.content: China and Taiwan marked the Lunar New Year by releasing videos showing their military capabilities, in the latest clash between the two. China released a video showing its jets and bombers flying against images of Taiwan's scenery, with the background lyrics calling upon "brothers and sisters" to "return". In response, Taiwan's military released a video, titled 'Freedom Is Not Free'.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Ivanka responds to art exhibit showing her vacuuming crumbs
data.content: Responding to an art exhibit showing her lookalike vacuuming crumbs, US President Donald Trump's daughter Ivanka Trump tweeted, "Women can choose to knock each other down or build each other up. I choose the latter." Ivanka is "a figure whose public persona incorporates an almost comically wide range of feminine identities– daughter, wife, mother...working woman," the exhibit's description read.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 4th person dies in 'menstruation hut' in Nepal this year
data.content: A 21-year-old woman has become the fourth person to die in Nepal this year after she was forced to stay in a 'menstruation hut' during her period under the practice of chhaupadi. She died due to smoke inhalation and suffocation as she closed the door of the windowless hut and lit a fire for warmth during the night, authorities said.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Trump to pick Treasury's Malpass to lead World Bank: Reports
data.content: President Donald Trump will reportedly pick senior Treasury official David Malpass as the US nominee to lead the World Bank. The 62-year-old is known to have earlier criticised the World Bank and other multilateral institutions for growing "intrusive" and "entrenched". World Bank's former President Jim Yong Kim stepped down on February 1 to join private equity firm Global Infrastructure Partners.
data.author: Shruti Maria Mahendar

data.title: Australia deploys military to tackle 'once-in-a-century' floods
data.content: Australia's military has been deployed after 'once-in-a-century' floods hit the state of Queensland last week following heavy rains. Two people have died in the floodwaters and thousands of residents in Townsville were without power and cut off by flooded roads. Around 400 residents in Townsville have sought shelter at nearby military barracks.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: 15 Thai election candidates change names to those of former PMs
data.content: Fifteen election candidates in Thailand have changed their names to those of former Prime Ministers in a bid to remain memorable to voters. While 10 men have legally changed their names to Thaksin, after former PM Thaksin Shinawatra, five women have changed their names to Yingluck, after the country's first female PM, Yingluck Shinawatra.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Will build a human wall at Mexico border if necessary: Trump
data.content: US President Donald Trump on Tuesday said that his country will build a 'human wall' along the border with Mexico if necessary by deploying troops to the border. His remarks come after the US announced last week that 3,750 additional soldiers were being sent to the Mexico border, bringing the total number to over 4,300.
data.author: Nandini Sinha

data.title: Twitter reacts to US Speaker's clap during Trump's speech
data.content: Following US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's clap for President Donald Trump during his State of the Union speech, a Twitter user wrote, "Pelosi the Gawd with the most pettiest and sarcastic clap possible." While one user tweeted, "Is this what the kids mean when they keep talking about a clap back?", another wrote, "Iconic picture for the ages."
data.author: Nandini Sinha
